title: 106_hr4035
content:
The "National Resource Governance Act of 2000" aims to address the rising energy prices, the importance of a domestic energy supply for the economy, and the need to reduce dependence on foreign energy sources, particularly OPEC. Congress establishes a commission to oversee these issues. The National Energy Self-Sufficiency Commission (referred to as the "Commission") is established to oversee issues related to rising energy prices, domestic energy supply, and reducing dependence on foreign energy sources, particularly OPEC. The National Energy Self-Sufficiency Commission is tasked with investigating issues related to energy importation and dependence on foreign sources. They aim to make the US self-sufficient in energy production by 2010, exploring alternative energy sources like ethanol, solar power, and wind energy. They also investigate the affordability of oil exploration in untapped areas. The National Energy Self-Sufficiency Commission is directed to oversee the progress and operation of the Commission, explore tax credits and incentives for alternative energy research, submit reports to Congress and the President, and consider environmental impacts in their proposals. The Act limits the Commission's authority. The National Energy Self-Sufficiency Commission oversees progress, explores tax credits for alternative energy research, and considers environmental impacts in proposals. The Act limits the Commission from recommending tax increases or import restrictions on oil or commodities. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, Senate Minority Leader, Speaker of the House, and House Minority Leader. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with a quorum of 5 members required for meetings. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by various officials, must have appointments made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The first meeting should occur within 90 days, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and members can continue for up to 90 days after leaving their original position. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION.

(a) Pay.--Each member of the Commission, whether a government employee or not, shall receive compensation for their duties. Non-government employees will receive a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government employees serve without additional pay.

(b) Travel.--Members will be reimbursed for travel and other necessary expenses incurred during their duties.

SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The chairman can also determine their compensation, not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can procure experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission has the power to procure experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission can hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and receive support services as needed. The Administrator of General Services will provide facilities and support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can utilize facilities and services from federal agencies upon request. They can also make expenditures and enter contracts for necessary supplies and services within budget limits. Additionally, the Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other federal departments and agencies. The Commission can accept gifts, services, and property. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of its first meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. It will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $3,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for the Commission.
